Hello <@U010JUMERV5> - Thank you for joining us. We have a folder in google drive where we are storing this types of information.

<https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1lVap5ylRncPf_dZA0b5qT_qZiUj0ziD7?usp=sharing>

Please review what we have and let us know if you have more information.

We also have a project to provide DIY protective gear that we are hoping to manufacture in Ethiopia. I will add you to that project if you can provide any guidance.

text:
These are a few advice/measures to think about...

1. The main measure to take for you and your department as this unfolds is to ISOLATE patients with symptoms/known contact/recent travel to affected areas. This should occur at triage/preop/ED as patients are coming in BEFORE they spread the virus to other patients and healthcare workers. Patient visitors should be completely banned to come into the hospital. We have stopped all patient visitors from entering the hospital here, unless it is a patient who is under 18, developmentally delayed, unable to communicate with staff etc. If you need dedicated translators for patients who don't speak amharigna, you can urge the hospital to work on providing translators so you can minimize the amount of people entering in and out of the hospital.
2. all patients who are coming into the hospital should be registered as they are coming in and out, including which department they are going to. this will help trace potential spread.
3. Cancel all electives cases, which you have already done. 
4. train essential staff (anesthesia, nursing, ICU, ED, ward nurses, surgeons) on proper use of PPE, particularly when taking it OFF which is when most of the contamination happens. you should have a dedicated trash bin where all materials contaminated with covid 19/PUI are thrown in. If you run out of N95 masks, try to think outside of the box, possibly urging hospital and MOH to manufacture clothes masks? the CDC here is starting to insinuate any mask might be useful...when there is nothing, anything is better. 
5. the minimum essentials for PPE is MASK (N95  preferably), GOWN, GLOVES and EYE COVER. OR staff will need shoe cover as well. 
6. run simulations (hands on practice) throughout the week on how to put PPE on and off. 
7. WASHING hands of all healthcare workers before and after caring for ANY patients should be strictly enforced.
8. All patients coming into the hospital should first wash their hands at the door, regardless if COVID or not.
9. warn staff NOT to take out masks outside of hospital to give to family members. this should come from higher up and should be strictly enforced. half of the reason why we are lacking masks here is because workers kept on taking them to their family.
10. staff # should be minimized. unnecessary staff should GO home. it is better to call staff on a need basis than expose everyone to the virus and run out of workforce. as elective cases get cancelled you will have many workers sitting around, tell them to go home and stay home, call them when you need them or as workers start getting sick, this will inevitably happen. 
11. you should also meet with ICU, anesthesia and EM team to come up with a coherent plan. if a patient who is suspected or affected comes in, what are the steps to intubation and ICU. this should be a uniform process. 
12. when the patient comes to the OR, he/should should wear a normal mask. 
13. for intubation, 2 providers a recommended. one who will intubate, the other one who can push drugs. intubation should be RSI for all patients, no LMA/masking as you are trying to minimize aerosolization of particles. the cuff should be inflated as soon as possible and connected to the circuit. the circuit once connected should not be disconnected FOR any reason, unless something discussed extensively with you or other team mates. if you need to suction patient, the tip of the suction should be contained after suction. here we have inline suction which is helpful, it is already connected to ETT. 
14. both intubating providers should have full PPE.
15. any health worker taking care of patient should have full PPE
hope this helps.

elements.text: These are a few advice/measures to think about...

The main measure to take for you and your department as this unfolds is to ISOLATE patients with symptoms/known contact/recent travel to affected areas. This should occur at triage/preop/ED as patients are coming in BEFORE they spread the virus to other patients and healthcare workers. Patient visitors should be completely banned to come into the hospital. We have stopped all patient visitors from entering the hospital here, unless it is a patient who is under 18, developmentally delayed, unable to communicate with staff etc. If you need dedicated translators for patients who don't speak amharigna, you can urge the hospital to work on providing translators so you can minimize the amount of people entering in and out of the hospital.
all patients who are coming into the hospital should be registered as they are coming in and out, including which department they are going to. this will help trace potential spread.
Cancel all electives cases, which you have already done.

train essential staff (anesthesia, nursing, ICU, ED, ward nurses, surgeons) on proper use of PPE, particularly when taking it OFF which is when most of the contamination happens. you should have a dedicated trash bin where all materials contaminated with covid 19/PUI are thrown in. If you run out of N95 masks, try to think outside of the box, possibly urging hospital and MOH to manufacture clothes masks? the CDC here is starting to insinuate any mask might be useful...when there is nothing, anything is better.
the minimum essentials for PPE is MASK (N95  preferably), GOWN, GLOVES and EYE COVER. OR staff will need shoe cover as well.
run simulations (hands on practice) throughout the week on how to put PPE on and off.
WASHING hands of all healthcare workers before and after caring for ANY patients should be strictly enforced.
All patients coming into the hospital should first wash their hands at the door, regardless if COVID or not.

warn staff NOT to take out masks outside of hospital to give to family members. this should come from higher up and should be strictly enforced. half of the reason why we are lacking masks here is because workers kept on taking them to their family.

staff # should be minimized. unnecessary staff should GO home. it is better to call staff on a need basis than expose everyone to the virus and run out of workforce. as elective cases get cancelled you will have many workers sitting around, tell them to go home and stay home, call them when you need them or as workers start getting sick, this will inevitably happen.

you should also meet with ICU, anesthesia and EM team to come up with a coherent plan. if a patient who is suspected or affected comes in, what are the steps to intubation and ICU. this should be a uniform process.
when the patient comes to the OR, he/should should wear a normal mask.

for intubation, 2 providers a recommended. one who will intubate, the other one who can push drugs. intubation should be RSI for all patients, no LMA/masking as you are trying to minimize aerosolization of particles. the cuff should be inflated as soon as possible and connected to the circuit. the circuit once connected should not be disconnected FOR any reason, unless something discussed extensively with you or other team mates. if you need to suction patient, the tip of the suction should be contained after suction. here we have inline suction which is helpful, it is already connected to ETT.
both intubating providers should have full PPE.
any health worker taking care of patient should have full PPE
hope this helps.

text: the above is an email I sent out to one of the  anesthesiologists in Addis Ababa  who reached out to me re  initial measures.  i am working on an  operating  room  protocol  for my department, i can send  that out once it's  finalized mid next  week. if  any specific anesthesiologist or  ICU doctor wants to reach out to me <mailto:asnake.betelehem@gmail.com|asnake.betelehem@gmail.com>. Please give  them my personal email, use the subject title  "Slack Covid ET"  thank you -

text: Hi everyone, we are looking for research support as we prepare to launch a daily Health Segment on the Local News (ETV or FANA) for ~10mins. Is there anyone interested in supporting this venture as a content researcher? As you know, creating print material is crucial, but we are not addressing the masses due to literacy issues. The segment will start in Amharic, but will quickly scale up to include additional local languages on TV and Radio. If you are interested in collaboration, please let me know. Thanks!

elements.text: Hi everyone, we are looking for research support as we prepare to launch a daily Health Segment on the Local News (ETV or FANA) for ~10mins. Is there anyone interested in supporting this venture as a content researcher? As you know, creating print material is crucial, but we are not addressing the masses due to literacy issues. The segment will start in Amharic, but will quickly scale up to include additional local languages on TV and Radio. If you are interested in collaboration, please let me know. Thanks!

text: <@U01087PJBNG> has joined the channel

Hello <@U0108RB6UU8> - Thank you for joining. Yes this is a very important project and we want to help. At the moment, we have a social awareness group that is creating a lot of print material. We are also working on videos that have high impact and cultural significance so it can be shared on TV and radio.

Would you like to have one of our awareness team reach out to?
Would you like to get in contact with doctors from within Ethiopia?
Would you like to get in contact with influencers or other people that already have content they have created?

Let me know and we can get things going.
I am one of the leads here and I am particularly interested in awareness via TV and radio.

Thank you

elements.text: Hello

- Thank you for joining. Yes this is a very important project and we want to help. At the moment, we have a social awareness group that is creating a lot of print material. We are also working on videos that have high impact and cultural significance so it can be shared on TV and radio.

Would you like to have one of our awareness team reach out to?
Would you like to get in contact with doctors from within Ethiopia?
Would you like to get in contact with influencers or other people that already have content they have created?

Let me know and we can get things going.
I am one of the leads here and I am particularly interested in awareness via TV and radio.

Thank you

elements.text: Is this information good to share with the healthcare folks?

text: I dont think we should share just yet, imo. This is a preliminary result with only 20 test patients. Many people are optimistic about this combination drug working, but there has not been a rigorous testing to prove that it works in reducing viral load or decreasing the symptomatic window of time.

elements.text: I dont think we should share just yet, imo. This is a preliminary result with only 20 test patients. Many people are optimistic about this combination drug working, but there has not been a rigorous testing to prove that it works in reducing viral load or decreasing the symptomatic window of time.
